nodes.text: Agents maximize the time-average growth rate of wealth and this growth-optimality can be identified with expected utility maximization by taking the ergodicity transformation as the utility function
Ergodicity economics (EE) distinguishes time averages from expectation values and posits individuals optimize time-average growth of wealth rather than expectation values

Expected utility theory (EUT) models agents as maximizing expected changes in a non-linear transformation of wealth called the utility function, interpreted psychologically and fitted to observed preferences

For general wealth dynamics there exists an ergodicity transformation u(x) such that the time-average growth rate of transformed wealth equals the expectation rate of change of u, enabling a correspondence between EE and EUT
Wealth dynamics are exogenous to preferences, so specifying dynamics predicts apparent utility functions and hence risk preferences; changes in dynamics imply changes in preferences

Expectation values are ensemble averages over many realizations and are not mechanistically relevant to a single agent who experiences a single trajectory; time averages are the relevant observable for individuals
If the increments of u(t) are stationary and independent then the observable r = delta u / delta t is ergodic and its time average equals its expectation value
For continuous-path processes with stationary independent increments u(t) must follow a Brownian motion with drift: du = a_u dt + b_u dW
Under the ergodicity condition the long-time growth rate r-bar exists and equals the drift parameter a_u of the Brownian motion for u

Applying Ito calculus, every invertible utility function u(x) that follows Brownian motion with drift corresponds to a unique It√¥ stochastic differential equation for wealth dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW
Theorem: For any invertible u(x) there exists a class of wealth dynamics such that maximizing expected changes in u is equivalent to maximizing time-average growth under those dynamics

Consequence: knowing an agent's wealth dynamics predicts their apparent utility function a priori; conversely, a specified utility function gives a physical interpretation as the underlying wealth dynamics

Examples: linear utility corresponds to additive Brownian wealth dynamics; logarithmic utility corresponds to multiplicative geometric Brownian motion; square-root utility yields mixed additive-multiplicative dynamics

Wealth distributions follow from the mapped dynamics because u(t) is normal (Brownian), so P_x(x,t) = P_u(u(x),t) du/dx; this yields interpretable population wealth distributions including heavy tails depending on dynamics
Experimental evidence: recent experiments with controllable wealth dynamics support EE prediction that dynamics strongly determine observed preferences
Unboundedness of u(x) is required in this framework because invertibility is needed to map to dynamics; bounded utilities lead to mathematical pathologies and are therefore undesirable
